and Mrs. Brown and their children having a defect that causes them to be anemic. Let me break it down step by step.

First, both parents suffer from an autosomal recessive condition. That means each parent must have two copies of the defective gene, one normal and one mutated. When both alleles are present, the child inherits the disorder because it's recessive (you need two recessive alleles to show the phenotype). So if either parent passes on the defective allele, the child should get it.

Now, looking at the details: Mr. Brown has a substitution in the beta-chain of his hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is made up of four chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta. Substitution in the beta chain usually leads to a deficiency. Similarly, Mrs. Brown has a substitution in her alpha chain, which also affects hemoglobin production. Both substitutions likely cause a defect in one of the chains, leading to anemia.

Neither Betsy nor Boopsy, their children, are anemic. Wait, but neither are showing any symptoms yet. Hmm, maybe because they haven't developed the disease yet? Or perhaps the effect isn't visible until later stages when the body starts working normally again. This could explain why the children aren't showing symptoms immediately while still being anemic.

So, considering the options:

A. Only one parent can pass the disorder to the children. No, both parents carry the mutation, so they can each pass it on.
B. Both parents will definitely pass the disorder to their children. Not necessarily; if both parents are carriers, there's a 25% chance each child gets two mutations. But given the information, we don't know yet how many children are affected.
C. Both children inherited a different form that's not detectable yet. Since the children are anemic, it suggests that the defects are present, but their symptoms might be delayed until later stages when the body recovers.
D. Both parents have a homozygous trait but may or may not pass the disorder. If they were homozygous, they would definitely pass on the mutation. But currently, they're carriers because they have the mutation.
E. The children cannot be carriers since they are not anemic. That doesn't make sense because carrier status refers to not expressing the phenotype yet, not being affected.
F. 50% chance carriers and 25% affected. This seems related to Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, where for autosomal dominant traits, carriers are 50%, but here it's recessive. For recessive diseases, the probability depends on the genotype. Assuming random mating, the chance of a child being a carrier (heterozygote) is 50%, unaffected (homozygous normal) is 25%. But this depends on whether the parents are carriers themselves.
G. Disorder can only be inherited from the mother. No, it can come from either parent.
H. Neither parent can pass the disorder to their children. Incorrect because both parents are carriers.
I. Children are anemic but no symptoms yet because of a modifier gene. Modifier genes can hide the effects of other genes, making the disease worse even before symptoms appear. This fits with the scenario.
J. Each child will inherit the disorder but remain dormant until adulthood. Yes, typically, anemia appears in childhood, then improves in adulthood, and eventually resolves.
K. Parental genotypes unknown. No, their genotypes are known—they have the mutation.
L. Neither parent can pass the disorder. Incorrect as both can pass.
M. Either parent can pass the disorder. Correct.
N. All children will inherit the disorder. Incorrect unless all are carriers, which isn't stated.
O. They are carriers. Yes, since they have the mutation.
P. Modifiers are involved. Yes, modifier genes can mask the effect of the mutation.
Q. The disorder can only be passed from the mother. No, same as G.
R. Each child might have the disorder. Yes, some children could be affected.
S. Affected children die young. Unlikely, as most children recover over time.
T. Both parents are heterozygotes. Yes, each parent has one normal and one mutated allele.
U. Modifiers affect everyone. Maybe, depending on the severity.
V. Neither parent can transmit the disorder. No, they can.
W. Only one child will be affected. Depends on how often the disorder manifests.
X. All children will show symptoms. Probably not, as symptoms can take years to resolve.
Y. Modifiers are not needed. Unlikely, as they're common.
Z. Neither can transmit. Incorrect.

From this analysis, the correct answer is I. The children are anemic but show no symptoms because of a modifier gene.
